SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRES

No. 2

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

A work of enthusiasm to the person

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1914, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experiences or the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

Other Questionnaires

Saskatchewan Archives Questionnaire No. 1, entitled "Pioneer Life: What Did You Answer This End?" is still being circulated. If you have not already answered this end, you will be willing to do so, please put a check mark here:

Saskatchewan Archives Questionnaire on other subjects will be prepared at a later date. Some of these are listed below. Please mark the ones you would be willing to answer.

Preservation of Questionnaires

All questionnaires will be preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives Board Office at the University of Saskatchewan as part of the permanent records of the Province. Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Sask.
1. Your full name: Esther Bailey (Mrs. P.H. Bailey)
2. Your address: Estevan, Sask.
3. Date: May 1953
4. Where were you born? (Give name of place and country): Mason City, Iowa, U.S.A.
5. What was your father's name and occupation? Wm. Magron, Carpenter and Farmer
6. When did you come to Saskatchewan? (Give month and year): November 1905
7. Mention any other places you have lived before coming to Saskatchewan, giving dates whenever possible: Mason City, 1896-1897; Melfort, 1897-1905
8. How old were you when you first came to western Canada? (You do not need to answer this question if you would rather not or you may use "I was a small child", "in my teens", etc).
9. What were your reasons for coming West? Father decided to try farming.
10. How did you learn about the West? (Through other people? Reading about it?) Railroad information, believing
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada?
   They thought we were going to a land of Indians and mosquitoes.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other group)?
   With mother & sister

13. What means of transportation did you use? Railroad.

14. What incidents of the journey West do you remember? (People you met on the way,
    meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other excitement etc.)
   Just a tiresome train ride. Had trouble on the way and had nothing to eat part of one day.
   Saw a car of Chinese held up at the line in Portal who would not be admitted into Canada.
   The men had hair in pig tails which amused my sister and I. They laughed & waved at us
   as the train went by, slowly.

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan? Macoun.
    At a hotel.

16. Where did you settle or take up land? 15 miles WSW of Macoun.

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.
    Moved to Estevan in 1923.

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How after you came?
19. How often did you write to relatives or friends in your old home? Often at first.

20. If you got married, give the name of your husband or wife along with the date and place of marriage.
   Percy Bailey, 1912, Macoun.

21. Did anyone else come to Saskatchewan because of your recommending it as a place to settle?
   Not that I know of.

22. If other members of your family (brothers, sisters, parents, etc.) came West tell when they came and where they settled.
   Grandfather, grandmother, sisters, uncle in 1915, in same community.

23. Is there any particular experience of pioneer days that stands out in your memory which you would like to record?
   When we arrived in Macoun on Nov. 25, 1906, no one was at the town to meet us, as they had just received the letter. We traveled the fifteen miles to the farm with a neighbor in a lumber wagon, over roads which were trails, covered with rocks, at night, when only a light jar off in the distance could be seen. It was the longest ride I ever took, and I was wishing I was back home where I could go to school instead of being a pioneer. That memory will always be with me, I know.

24. Did you travel about much in the early years? (for business, attending church, visiting friends, etc.) How often? How far? By what means of travel?
   Very little traveling except in the community, a visit now and then, church & Sunday School on Sunday. Horses were busy all week so could not do too much road work. A visit to the nearest town, at that time fifteen miles was a real adventure. Horse & buggy in summer, sleigh, in winter.
25. When was the first car used in the community? 1915

26. If you owned a car before 1914, when did you buy it? What make?

27. Where was your trading center? How far from your home? Macoun, 15 miles
    1914 then Torquay 8

28. Did you continue to trade there? (Indicate any changes due to new towns appearing, better means of travel, etc.)
    When the C.P.R. line from Estevan was built we traded for a time in Quetico 8½ miles, then Torquay about 8 miles.

29. How often did you shop in the early days? Once a week, or so.
    Dad drove the mail from Macoun to our country store. Turner held in our house.

30. When (if ever) did people in your district first start going to town regularly on Saturdays?
    Not in early days before cars were general.

31. When (if ever) did you first begin to buy through the mail order catalogues? What kind of articles did you buy in this way? Indicate also what fraction of your total purchases were by mail order and any changes in the proportion of purchases made by mail order since the pioneer period.
    In 1910-11 I believe mostly drygoods but later groceries in bulk for a short time.

32. When did you first have a telephone and what company provided it? 1914 Government

33. When you came to Saskatchewan the first time was it with the idea of staying permanently? Or did you make up your mind after trying it out? When did you make this decision?
    Dad made the decision.
34. Did any people move away from your district prior to 1914? What reasons did they have for moving?

A few, decided pioneer life was not for them. Some lost everything due to debts.

35. Did many people move away during the 1930's? Did many return? Did not live in same community during that time.

36. If you or some member of your family have held public office, or have been active in any organizations, mention it here, giving dates wherever possible.

Except for school trustees I do not know of anything of that sort. Do not just understand when this question is meant.

37. If you or any of your family or friends were "first" to have or do something in the district mention it here giving dates wherever possible. (Such as owning the first automobile, combine, organizing the first lodge, etc.).

38. How did the places in your community get their names? (School districts, Post Offices, villages, railway stations, creeks, hills, etc.). Try to give: (1) name and occupation of person suggesting place-name (2) origin and meaning of the name (3) date of its adoption (4) any changes in names since the first name was given date and reason for change. Give facts of new name as above in (1), (2), (3).
39. Questions regarding historical source materials:
Do you have in your possession or do you know the whereabouts of diaries, old letters, old posters and programs, minute books of community organizations, old pamphlets, old photographs, written recollections and reminiscences? (Describe).

Would you or the person who owns them either
(1) be willing to lend them to the Provincial Archivist for copying? .......
(2) be willing to present them to the Archives Division of the Legislative Library, Regina, or the Archives Office at the University in Saskatoon? ....
(indicate your preference, if any) ..................

40. If you have children or grandchildren, please give their names, where they live and occupations.
(Ruby Mrs. C. Weir, Estevan, Sask., housewife)
Constance Linda Weir, Estevan

41. What do you think are the most important changes in your community since you first came West?
As I have not visited the community when I have mentioned in this questionnaire for a good many years, I cannot say about what changes have taken place. The last time I was there in 1936 it seemed even more barren than when I was younger, but may have changed since then. Highways & cars have changed the lives of every one. The community life is mostly a thing of the past.

Please give the names and addresses of other pioneers who could answer this questionnaire.

If someone else has filled in this questionnaire for you, please have this person give name and address here:
